lines.text: Two tickets to Niagara Falls, please.
Oh. Congratulations, ma'am. What train?
20, and I want to stop off at Ossining.
Ossining? You mean, Sing-Sing?
No, I mean Ossining.
Well, hello Kay! Here you are, here's a seat for you.
The further I sit from you, Mr. Welch, the better I like it.
[to Porter]
Take those bags into the next car, please.
Sorry, Miss. The train's full up today.
Here you are, Kay. Sit right down here.
[Kay drops train tickets, and Welch picks them up]
Two tickets to Niagara Falls, eh? How romantic. That's where honeymooners go. Oh, yes. Eddie Ellison gets out today. Say, you're not really gonna marry that guy, are you?
Any objection?
Say, listen, kid. I like you. I want to give you a little friendly advice.

[scoffs]
Friendly advice. Well, that's good, coming from the fellow that caused Eddie's conviction.
Now take it easy, Kay. I'm telling you that I'm your friend. More than a friend.
Yes, you tried to be more than a friend, ever since you had Eddie arrested.
Now, don't be that way. You're a nice girl, and you're about to make the mistake of your life.
That's my business.
You're a nice girl and you're about to make the biggest mistake of your life.
That's my business.
Sure it is, and don't let him tell you any different!
We're not going back to the city, Eddie. I've got a big surprise.
What is this, a practical joke?
It's no joke, but boy it's practical. We're going to Niagra Falls.
You mean, right now? From here?
The train leaves in half an hour.
Gee, you're swell and I'm the luckiest man in the world.
Luck had nothing to do with it. You couldn't get away from me if you tried.
I tried to hide from you in prison and it was hopeless.
Well, if it isn't my old pal Welch, big as life and twice as natural.
He's still got it in for you! He's been giving the one-two the whole way up here, trying to promote himself.
I was just trying to give Kay here a little friendly advice. I know a lot more about crooks than she does.
Why, you!
[he tries to punch Welch, but Larry stops him]
If you slug him, you'll get in trouble. You're on your way out. Keep going. I'm on my way in. I got nothing to lose.
[he punches Welch]
Did you tell her about her present?
Who, me? Gee, won't she look cute in that?
Oh, it's darling.
It cost an awful lot.
It's for Shirley, isn't it? She only has a birthday once a year.
Every day is her birthday with you.
Well, why shouldn't it be? Say, here's another littl gadget I bought for Shirley.
What is it?
Take a look.
[He hands Larry a small telescope. When Larry looks into it, it leaves a black ring around his eye]
I don't see anything.
No, but we do!
Oh, Eddie, you and your tricks. You're not going to give that to the baby. You're making her as bad as you are.
Sleeping sickness, get up.
What time is it?
What time do you want? It's time for you to get out of that bed.
I wasn't sleeping, I was thinking.
Get up! Your breakfast will be spoiled!
[She hits him]
Ow! Hey, what are you doing?
Top of the morning to you.
And the heat of the evening to you.
Sit down and have some coffee.
Aren't you going to wait for Eddie?
I should wait and eat a cold breakfast? Not for any husband. Sometimes I get so mad I could give him poison.
And sometimes I get so mad I could take it. What do you know about that?
To hear you two in the morning, you'd think you were ready to jump at each other's throats.
In the morning? What about the rest of the day?
Well, I just hope Jane and me get along as well as you two.
Eddie, Larry and Jane got engaged last night!
Well, I don't see why a fine girl like Jane would want to marry a mug like you.
So you're Eddie Ellison's kid.
I'm not a kid, I'm a girl, and today is my birthday.
Sometimes I wonder if going straight really pays.
Hey, cut out that kind of talk, will you?
But what will Jane think?
She's a hundred percent for you. She wouldn't think anything bad about you any more than Kay would me. We won't tell them anything tonight, though.
Why not?
I don't want anything to spoil Shirley's birthday party!
I want to thank you all for my presents. Thank you very, very much. And I hope that someday when it's your birthday, I can give them all back to you.
Eddie, when you were admitted here, I gave you a choice of two roads to take. You took the right one, and it got four months off your stretch for you. Now, will you let me advise you again?
Certainly, sir.
Something kept up your morale while you were up here.
You're a good guesser, Warden.
Well, whatever it was, stick to it outside. Have you got a job waiting for you?
The biggest and best job a man ever had.
Good wages?
Not a cent.
Well, but how - ?
I've had a girl waiting for me for eighteen months.
Congratulations, my boy. The very best of luck.
Well, if it isn't my old pal, Welch. As big as life and twice as natural.
He's no pal of yours, fella. He's still got it in for you.
What do you mean?
He's been throwing hooks into you all the way up on the train. Trying to promote himself.
Yeah. I was just trying to give her a little friendly advice, that's all. I happen to know a lot more about crooks than she does.
Why, you -
[moves as if to hit Welch]

[restraining him]
Eddie, Eddie!
If you sock him, you'll get into trouble. You're on the way out. Keep going. I'm on the way in, so I've got nothing to lose.
[punches Welch in the nose]
Thanks, fella. I'll be seeing you when you get out.
Good luck. I wish I could be your best man.
Daddy, come here. Tell me what you bought me for a birthday present.
Oh, no. That's a secret.
Will you tell me if I guess?
Well, maybe.
A pair of roller skates?
No.
A dollhouse?
No.
Aw, Daddy. If you tell me, I'll tell you what I'm going to get you for your birthday.
Oh, no. I want to be surprised.
Will you tell me for a kiss?
Well, that's awful tempting, but...
I'll bet I know, a ballet dress.
A ballet dress. Now, what made you think of that?
Cause that's what I want most.
Come on, now, you little g-nomey, you've gotta go to sleep. Go on.

[singsong]
I'm gonna get a ballet dress. I'm gonna get a ballet dress.

[singsong]
Don't tell Mommy I told you.

[singsong]
I won't.
Say, how 'bout going to the movies with us tonight?
Oh, thanks, but we can't leave Shirley.
They're showing 10,000 years in Sing-Sing at the Cameo.
Gee, what a long stretch!
They say it's awful funny.
Not for my dough.
Well, come on, Jane. We'll be late.
Say, Larry, what's your hurry? If you miss three or four years, it don't make any difference.
Have a good time.
Thanks. Sorry you won't come with us. So long.
Good-bye.
Oh. Hey, Larry.
Yeah?
We've got to be on the job early in the morning. Stop by for me, and we'll dunk a couple of doughnuts.
Right.
And say, let me know what the guy did to get 10,000 years.
What's happened?
Well, the breadwinners have stopped winning.
Yeah, looks like we're in for a little vacation.
You mean you were discharged.
Well, not exactly. We were canned.
But they can't let you off for nothing.
No. I know they can't. But they did. Welch saw to that.
Who's Welch?
Well, he's an old friend of ours.
Will you excuse us for a minute? I want to talk to Eddie alone.
[Eddie and Kay go into the next room]
Now listen, Eddie. When we were married we said we'd go 50-50 on everything, didn't we?
Uh-huh.
Well, that meant joy and trouble, too. You always let me in on the joy, now. Why not the trouble?
There's nothing more to tell.
Eddie, look at me. Did Larry have anything to do with this?
No.
Well, then. We haven't a thing to worry about.

[Welch is searching Eddie's apartment for a stolen pearl necklace]
What kind of a sap do you think I am?
I don't know. What kind of a sap are you?
Now, let's see. If I was in your spot, I wonder where I'd hide that necklace.
Let me see. Maybe you'd swallow it.
I read in Popular Mechanics where Zulus hide jewels by sewing them under their skin.
That'd be all right if we were Zulus.

[Trigger Stone is lying tied up on the floor]
Hey, mister, your beads were lost, but I found them.
That's fine. You're a smart little girl. Now, go on, cut me loose.
Are you playing the game, too?
Of course I am. Your old man tied me up so I couldn't peek. Let's you and me fool him.
Do you think that would be fair?
Why, sure, it would. It'll be a big joke. We'll all bust laughing. Now, go on. Get something, and cut me loose.
Won't your dad be surprised when he finds out I'm gone.
You said he'd bust laughing.

[to Shirley]
Baby, take a bow.
